The Northern California fires hit houses in the late evening in minutes with little communication.  Being vigilante and ready seems to be the state of affairs for us as citizens.  Our President is focused on fake news and NFL millionaires instead of the working people in the US.   Stand together and recognize that the help will be coming from neighbor and community.   Volunteer, prepare and protect those that you may never have met.

IT Dist Ops Supervisor - my role now is integration lead supporting only the ADMS deliverable. For 2016, many changes in my career has taken affect.  Our ADMS project expands and has two phases with a focus on Outage Management for January 2017 and a transition to Distribution SCADA in 2018.  The team has expanded my role has changed to support the core integration areas.  The complex challenges of multiple system major upgrades and different timelines for each has made the targets require routable integrations based on the versions of technology and no one set expectation to hit.  My team has transitioned to an overall Agile approach for integration, testing and resource management.  The next phase is to embrace the DevOps methodology as we transition out of the project and more into supporting the new technologies.

John Peters is a savvy business professional with an extremely strong technical background.  His systems thinking capability along with his business analysis experience provide a combination that is not only rare, but extremely valuable.  If I am building a team to manage a difficult business and technical issue, John is one of the first people I want on it.  To put it another way, John is a person I really don't want on my competitor's team.

July 31, 2017, John was VICTOR  CATAÑO’S teacher

Victor was my student in MGMT404 - Project Management.  This course gives the basics around Project Management and discusses leadership for undergrad students.When I look at recommending a student, I consider more than someone's academic grade.  Victor was one of my top students in my ten years of teaching Project Management.  Here's some of his skills - Contribution - Victor participated in class in a professional manner and provided excellent insight from his experience in the military as a special forces technician.   Accountability - During his time in my class, his medical conditions required him to do some catching that doubled his workload during our session together.  He communicated the situation to me and stayed later in class to better understand the assignments which made him have more time for the make up areas.  This proactive attitude is the difference that stood out to me.Aptitude - I have interviewed many students for positions in Networking, Quality Analysis and Development.  Many coming to me for positions have seemed to not have the interest in IT at all.  Victor not only is interested in networking but has the passion to maintain his aptitude in it.  He has the years in the military to get a position at most places without a degree but recognized to lead a team of professionals a degree would provide  the educational aptitude and integrate his experience.We are growing at Epiq and I am hoping that we can find a position for him at our location.   He would fit into any DevOps team and understands going to battle to get the job done.  Anyone hiring Victor is getting a great man and an exceptional talent in his field.  - John Peters, Devry Professor - 2007-17 (Phoenix)

Don Harper-Smith
Senior Solutions Consultant T&D Operations ABB
July 31, 2017, John worked with Don in different groups

Getting ADMS Live - 2016 was a challenging year and go-live was real for January 25, so we were told that we had 1000+ manhours of Data Corrections to make before cutover and time was running short with four weeks left before go-live.   All of us, especially Don, recognized that we had to get those changes into production.  Don put together a team of folks across the 24 hour operational shifts along with coordinated my team on the application side to stand up the first ADMS Clients in production in mid-December.  We were still in UAT but we in reality we were live and the operational team was using ADMS.  By January 20, all the data have been moved.  Don worked normal hours supporting the testing and the odd hours supporting the operational teams.   Tenacious is the word that comes to my mind and in the business with millions of customers and multiple data points per customer - that is the only way to keep the lights on without people getting hurt - troublemen and the utility customers were always in the front of Don's concerns.   Our ADMS upgrade did not take a system outage to transition to.  Our customers went from one system to the other during shift change without the customer call center going down.  The team just logged in to the new systems and went to work that day.  We were testing our back up site three days into the cutover.  One month later we upgraded the customer and proved again that it was not a fluke and had no outage to the end users.  The data migration happened while operations maintained use of their application in a seamless transition.  Don believed in me and my team when I told him that I was using distribution processes in my application integration design and we could do our upgrades in without customer impacts.  It was his trust in my approach and support that made that dream a reality - thank you Don.  Another fun discussion - Legacy DOMS - I cannot go into all the war stories about keeping our legacy OMS up and running.  When I had an operational challenge, I called Don and my team to meetings to get the system back up and running.  We had some special days where our network switches failed, database crashed due to GIS bad data, and just overall crazy memory leaks.   Don was my operational partner that explained that this IT guy was not nuts and would get the system back up..  Again  - thank you Don.  It was fun - well weird fun.-- John Peters, ADMS OMS Integration Leader and Distribution Operations IT Supervisor.
